results.title: Marvel, a Jakarta Boy
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours. Indonesia”.
A day in the life of a 14 year old boy. Marvel comes from a migrant Minangkabau family, seeking a new way of life in the busy city of Jakarta. He sells rice cakes to the taxi drivers outside the tourist hotels. His father is a middle man in a small “Pasar”.

results.title: Sinagas family: a Batak village
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours. Indonesia”.
Set in a small fishing village on the edge of Lake Toba, Borneo, inhabited by fifteen Christian families. Sinaga, head of one of these families, fishes for his living as well as being a rice farmer.

results.title: Pak Menggung: a Javanese aristocrat
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Keith Gow, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours. Indonesia”.
Java is no longer ruled by kings and queens. The aristocrats who remain live in their palaces, but they are mostly poor. When they die so will many of their traditions. This passing history is recorded by following the daily life of Pak Menggung, writer and collector of ancient Keris. This film gives insight into the courtly traditions of art, etiquette and ceremony of Java. Photography is by famous Australian cinematographer, Don McAlpine.

results.title: Mastri: a Balinese woman
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours. Indonesia”.
Mastri and Sukit are a young couple from the village on Tunjuk in South Bali. Sukit is a school teacher. They live in the house of Sukit’s parents and are saving their money to build a house of their own. Tunjuk has its own small dance company and Gong orchestra which is sometimes invited to perform at the tourist hotels around Denpasar, and Mastri is one of the principal dancers. The film contrasts normal village life with the “tourist’s” Bali and shows something of the religious life of the people of Tunjuk. Camerman Don McAlpine.

results.title: The Bupati of Subang: a government official
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours. Indonesia”.
The Bupati is the Government’s chief civilian Administrator in the West Javanese Kabupaten of Subang. His decisions affect the lives of a million people. Assisted by his military background, the Bupati, directly responsible to the Governor of West Java, administers his many responsibilities keeping peace, and harmony in the villages. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary school levels.

results.title: The Break with tradition
results.creator_credit: Leslie Ann Nathan, Eve Cotton and Center for Humanities
results.brief_description: This program introduces viewers to the origins of modern art - a change from art representing reality to art for art’s sake. It explains one of the most revolutionary aspects of impressionist painting - the use of colour - as seen in the works of Monet, Pissarro and Renoir.

results.title: The Bronte sisters
results.creator_credit: Peter Hort, Skan Productions and Vermont Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Famous authors”.
Filmed in and around the village of Haworth in Yorkshire where the Bronte sisters spent most of their short lives, this program gives a biographical account of this most extraordinary literary family.

results.title: The Boys who came home: recollections of Gallipoli
results.creator_credit: Harvey Broadbent, Paul Montgomery and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This documentary features interviews with veterans of the Gallipoli campaign. Through recollections, photographs and archival film, the history of Australia’s involvement in World war I is explored. The video includes interviews with Turkish veterans of the battle who offer their own stories of tragic loss. The documentary concludes by following a group of Australian veterans who return to the Turkish coast to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli campaign. The video includes footage of the official Dawn Service at Gallipoli on the 75th Anniversary of the dawn landing attended by Prime Minister Hawke.
